results.title: How Rodrigo Duterte Can Stay No. 1 by Becoming No. 2
results.abstract: The president of the Philippines says he’ll run for the vice presidency next year. Critics see a plot to avoid prosecution for the killings in his drug war.

results.title: Populist Hero or Demagogue: Who Is Tunisia’s President?

results.title: In First Interview From Jail, an Upbeat Navalny Discusses Prison Life
results.abstract: Russian political prisoners today are subjected to “psychological” pressure, said the opposition leader Aleksei A. Navalny, who is forced to watch state TV for more than eight hours a day.

multimedia.caption: Aleksei A. Navalny in May. “Imagine something like a Chinese labor camp,” he said of his prison experience, adding, “There is constant control and a culture of snitching.”

results.title: N.Y.C. lays out safety measures for public schools as Delta variant rises.
results.abstract: The city’s school testing program will be smaller than last year, and only unvaccinated students will have to quarantine if exposed to the virus.

multimedia.caption: At a summer school at P.S. 15 in Red Hook, Brooklyn, last month.
multimedia.copyright: James Estrin/The New York Times

results.title: In a German first, Hamburg will allow merchants to insist on vaccinations.

multimedia.caption: Businesses in Hamburg, Germany, will soon be allowed to voluntarily bar entry to the unvaccinated.
multimedia.copyright: Hayley Austin for The New York Times

results.title: Guam tries (and mostly fails) to lure tourists back with vaccines.

multimedia.caption: Tumon Bay beach in Guam last week. The country once welcomed 1.7 million visitors a year. That number has fallen to a tiny trickle.
multimedia.copyright: Anthony Henri Oftana for The New York Times
